The popularity of quaternions is mostly due to culture and the need of humans to share a norm for communicating rotations. Quaternions are often called the space of rotation, but it is worth mentionning that quaternions are more specifically the space of rotations up to two full turns. Why two? Quaternions are often used to represent the orientation of a 3D object, but an orientation represented by a quaternion is not unique: for example (0,0,0,1) and (0,0,0,-1) represent the same orientation yet these quaternions must be squared to come to that conclusion. The number two of full turns embedded in quaternions finds its origin in the history of their invention, and the arbitrary value of two full turns puts in question the practicality of the representation. Squaring quaternion reduce that arbitary number to a single full turn, and the simpler axis-angle representation defines a space where the number of turns can be infinite and is in fact the space used to interpolate quaternions. Despite the simpler representations, we will probably keep using quaternions for a very long time simply because we have invested too much in them already, and because the word quaternion sounds really cool, and because we lack imagination for naming squared-quaternions or axis-angle.

I first watched this video, a few of the interactive programs, and the original quaternion video when each was first released and I really didn't understand them much at all. Today, I was going over them again (taking another shot at learning some graphics programming) and I had a startling realization that was not accessible to me the first time around. The process for utilizing quaternions to rotate a point/vector depicted in this video (q p q^-1) is not only similar to rotations in linear algebra using linear transformations in matrix form, like R A R^-1 for a rotation matrix R (something I realized the first time) but the specific form of the acting quaternion q and its inverse q^-1 are eerily the same as the form of the rotation operator/transformation for the spin state of a quantum particle. In the video above, the rotation quaternion q takes the form of cos(t/2)+sin(t/2)*(x*i + y*j + z*k) where (x,y,z) is the unit vector describing the axis of rotation and 't' is the angle of rotation. The spin rotation operator is cos(t/2)*E - i*sin(t/2)*(x*sx + y*sy + z*sz) where (x,y,z) is the unit vector describing the axis of rotation, 't' is the angle of rotation, E is the identity operator (in matrix form it is a diagonal matrix of 1's), and (sx,sy,sz) are the Pauli spin operators for the x,y and z directions respectively.

In fact, while writing this comment, I realized that the two things (quaternions and quantum spin mechanics) are, nearly algebraically identical. Just like the quaternions, the set of Pauli spin operators are anti commutative (i*j = -j*i, sx*sy = -sy*sx), the product of 2 components equals + or - the third (i*j=k, sx*sy=sz); the only significant difference I can find is when one element is multiplied by itself: i*i=j*j=k*k=-1, but sx*sx=sy*sy=sz*sz=E, not -E.


Basically, undergraduate quantum mechanics was apparently a prerequisite to quaternions for me.

I need to reiterate that the mechanism of rotation with quaternions becomes much simpler to understand when the unit quaternions are seen as the planes of rotation, instead of axes. Rotation only happens around axes in 3D space, as a coincidence of combinatorics.

Treating the linear vectors as distinct from planes of rotation (bivectors), as in geometric algebra, makes this all much easier to visualize and work with, as well as extensible to other dimensionalities and even metrics (see: the Space Time Algebra of Minkowski Space).

Also, have you ever looked at the construction of a 3D rotation matrix? Those things are nightmarish to behold, and require other weird 3D-kludge constructions like a "cross-product matrix" to write down in any remotely tolerable form.

projection of a Hemisphere of "vision"
(d+1)(sin A)/(d+cos A) = U ; A< magnitude of + or - 90° ; when d < 0 it is undefined
where d is the distance from the center of the "cut" unit sphere of vision; A is the angle from the center of the projection; and the projection being one unit in front of the center of the unit sphere and U being the unit distance from center of projection.
When d = 0 it's rectilinear ( U = tan A)
= 1 it's stereographic
< 0 it's pincushion (A undefined when cos^-1(d+1) > A )
= infinity it's fisheye (the limit when d tends towards infinity (d+1)/(d+cos A) = 1 ; so U = sin A)
I wasn't able to find an elegant way to get the stereographic image to behave beyond 90°, seeing as I was doing my best to keep the function continuous for the variable d. My guess is that it might be related to the function at -1 as it mirrors the back hemisphere at that point.

Intersection of longitudinal and latitudinal points
tan^-1((sin X)/(tan Y)) = W
sin ^-1(((sin Y)^2)+((cos Y)(sin X))^2)^(1/2) = V
where X is the longitude and Y is the latitude; W is the angle from the equator at the center of the projection; and V is the angular distance from the from the center of the projection
